value.title: Dev Toolbox
value.summary: A mobile-first, self-hosted developer environment designed to keep context, reasoning, and feedback visible — enabling sustained development on the go without cognitive drift.
value.ownership: I owned problem framing, prioritization, and delivery decisions end-to-end, iterating the product through sustained real-world daily use.
value.successCriteria: Success meant making mobile development reliable: preserving context across sessions, making system behavior observable, and reducing cognitive switching while shipping real work.
value.problem: Mobile software development was fragmented and unreliable. Existing tools buried context, obscured system behavior, and made it difficult to resume work without losing reasoning or intent. Feedback existed, but it was scattered and disconnected from decision-making.
value.context: Dev Toolbox began as a response to friction I experienced personally. My systems-thinking and restorative instincts pushed me toward a unified workspace — one where planning, execution, logs, and reasoning stayed connected so learning could feed directly back into the work.
value.solution: I designed and built a self-hosted, mobile-first developer environment that treats feedback and context as first-class system properties. The platform evolved through real daily use to support planning, version control, structured logs, and explainable reasoning — keeping intent, behavior, and outcome aligned.
keyDecisions: Optimized for mobile-first development rather than desktop parity
Consolidated editing, planning, logs, and context to reduce cognitive switching
Favored structured workflows (sessions, sprints, work items) over ad-hoc flexibility
Chose a self-hosted architecture to preserve control, extensibility, and data ownership
Validated decisions through sustained personal use rather than speculative feature planning
value.impact: Dev Toolbox made sustained mobile development practical by restoring predictable feedback loops and preserving reasoning across sessions. Work became easier to resume, decisions more traceable, and iteration safer — reducing drift between intent and implementation.
tradeoffs: Prioritized mobile-first predictability over full desktop feature parity
Deferred multi-user collaboration to strengthen core planning and feedback workflows
Accepted higher setup complexity in exchange for long-term control and data ownership
innovations: Always-visible structured logs and system traces
Unified planning with sprints, sessions, and work items
AI context packet bundling for explainable reasoning

screenshots.alt: Code editor showing structured context metadata and backend route definitions
screenshots.caption: The editor pairs code with explicit contextual metadata, keeping structure, intent, and implementation visible together.

screenshots.alt: Project planner showing active sprint status and work item progress
screenshots.caption: The project planner surfaces sprint state and work-in-progress, grounding daily execution in clear structure.

screenshots.alt: Live logs view showing structured backend activity and request traces
screenshots.caption: Live, structured logs make system behavior observable and explainable while you work.

tech.ids: typescript react vite supabase postgres github cloudflare
bullets: Frontend: React & TypeScript bundled with Vite.
Backend & data: Supabase (Postgres + auth) with RLS and group-scoped tables.
Infrastructure: Cloudflare Pages and Tunnels. Workflow: GitHub integration, structured logs, and AI context packets.

value.title: Finance Tools / Simplicity
value.summary: A calm, mobile-first budgeting system that emphasizes signal over noise — helping users make confident decisions through clear, revisitable financial feedback.
value.role: Product lead responsible for problem framing, UX decisions, and implementation
value.ownership: I owned discovery framing, product decisions, UX direction, and delivery, iterating based on observed behavior and recurring decision points.
value.successCriteria: Success meant users could understand their financial state at a glance, anticipate upcoming obligations, and adjust proactively without relying on alerts or dense dashboards.
value.problem: Most budgeting tools overwhelm users with dashboards and alerts while failing to support real financial behavior. Feedback is either too noisy or too late, making it difficult to understand what actually needs attention.
value.context: Simplicity was shaped by an adaptive systems mindset: meet people where they are, reduce cognitive load, and make financial state understandable at a glance. The goal was not exhaustive reporting, but honest, actionable feedback.
value.solution: I designed and built a mobile-first budgeting system focused on clarity and revisability. The product highlights upcoming obligations, category health, and headroom — allowing users to orient quickly, adjust plans, and learn from patterns over time.
keyDecisions: Designed for frequent, lightweight mobile check-ins
Favored predictable, revisitable flows over complex interactions
value.impact: Simplicity helps users make calmer, more confident day-to-day decisions by closing the loop between financial intent and actual behavior. Instead of reacting to alerts, users can understand their situation and adjust proactively.
innovations: Calm, mobile-first interface designed to reduce stress
Predictable review flows that reinforce learning over time

screenshots.alt: Home dashboard showing bank balances, credit cards, and cash outlook
screenshots.caption: Home dashboard provides a calm snapshot of balances, credit cards, and estimated cash after bills.

screenshots.alt: Transaction history with categorized spending and income entries
screenshots.caption: Transaction history emphasizes clarity and organization through consistent categorization.

screenshots.alt: Monthly budget view with income items and bills
screenshots.caption: Budget view supports forward-looking planning by showing income items and bills in a single timeline.

bullets: React + TypeScript frontend with Supabase backend and Postgres RLS.
Built alongside Dev Toolbox to share schema introspection and documentation workflows.

value.title: Transportation Scheduling Workflow (GAS)
value.summary: A unified scheduling and coordination workflow that reduced dropped handoffs by treating feedback and data integrity as system responsibilities.
value.role: Product owner for internal scheduling and coordination workflow
value.ownership: I identified the coordination failure, gathered requirements from stakeholders, prioritized reliability over informal flexibility, and delivered the workflow end-to-end.
value.successCriteria: Success meant fewer dropped handoffs and conflicts, higher schedule completeness, and reduced manual reconciliation for assignments and billing.
value.problem: Transportation coordination relied on fragmented communication across emails, spreadsheets, and verbal handoffs. Feedback was delayed or lost entirely, leading to conflicts, errors, and repeated rework.
value.solution: Introduced a single, shared workflow that centralized requests, schedules, assignments, and costs. By consolidating where information lived, the system made state visible and errors harder to miss.
keyDecisions: Treat coordination failures as workflow problems, not people problems
Consolidate information into a single source of truth
Favor repeatable structure over informal workarounds
impact: More complete and reliable schedule data
Fewer dropped handoffs and scheduling conflicts
Reduced reconciliation effort and billing errors
tradeoffs: Required behavior change and more consistent update discipline
Reduced informal flexibility in favor of reliability

screenshots.alt: Transportation request responses captured in a shared spreadsheet used as the operational source of truth
screenshots.caption: Form submissions flowed into a shared sheet, keeping requests and schedule data consistent and visible.

screenshots.alt: Workflow diagram showing Form → Sheets → Calendar automation for transportation scheduling
screenshots.caption: Apps Script connected Forms, Sheets, and Calendar so requests created schedule events automatically and stayed in sync.

value.title: Operations & Logistics
value.summary: A body of operations leadership focused on clarity, feedback, and reliable execution in complex, people-driven environments.
value.role: Operations leader, workflow designer, logistics coordinator
value.framing: This operations experience shaped how I work as a product manager — grounding product judgment in real constraints, accountability, cross-functional coordination, and delivery under pressure.
outcomes: Led teams of 28–40+ employees with improved consistency and reliability
Improved operational visibility through structured reporting and feedback loops
evidence: Directed operations across 250,000–450,000 sq. ft. of facilities while maintaining service quality.
Led and coached teams of 28–40+ employees, improving day-to-day reliability and clarity.
Achieved industry-recognized CIMS certification with honors.
Sustained productivity at 43,000 sq. ft. per FTE with high customer satisfaction.
Built automated reporting + workflow tools (including a Google Apps Script scheduling system) that improved visibility and reduced errors.

items: Designed and refined workflows and inspection processes to ensure consistent quality across large operational footprints.
Implemented and maintained industry standards, achieving CIMS certification with honors.
Developed reporting tools that improved visibility and reduced manual steps.
Used CMMS to structure work orders, scheduling, and quality feedback loops.
Directed daily operations across facilities and logistics environments ensuring compliance, quality, and timeliness.
Coordinated transportation logistics for athletics, academic departments, and student activities.
Supported construction, renovation, and campus event operations through resource planning and cross-department alignment.
Supervised teams of 28–40+ employees, providing structured coaching and performance development.
Served as operational liaison across Residence Life, Events, Athletics, and Administration.
Led onboarding, training, and systems adoption during staffing changes.

highlights: Directed daily operations and served as liaison to Residence Life.
Conducted structured inspections and coached staff to improve consistency.
Ensured OSHA and regulatory compliance.
Managed payroll systems and employee databases (Kronos, HCMS).
Used CMMS for scheduling, assignment, and tracking of work orders.
Coordinated transportation logistics for athletics, departments, and student activities.

Developed a Google Apps Script workflow that unified vehicle schedules, driver assignments, and departmental requests into a single automated reporting system, reducing manual coordination effort and improving visibility.
Managed CMMS, payroll, AP/AR, and customer service workflows.
Created automated reporting tools to improve operational visibility.
Managed hiring workflows and supported employee engagement efforts.
Supervised and coached 40+ staff with structured expectations and quality controls.
Conducted inspections and implemented corrective workflows.
Mentored five team leads, improving leadership and consistency.
Implemented CIMS standards, earning full certification with honors.
Directed operations for 450,000 sq. ft. of facilities.
Supported campus events, alumni functions, and summer conferences.
Maintained productivity at 43,000 sq. ft. per FTE with high satisfaction.
Participated in labor conversion efforts creating student employment opportunities.
Directed custodial, maintenance, and grounds operations for a 250,000 sq. ft. campus.
Coordinated construction, renovation projects, and facility planning.
Managed equipment maintenance contracts and operational budgeting.
Executed high-volume delivery operations using RF/WMS technology.
Maintained accuracy and timeliness under strict delivery constraints.
Provided reliable customer service in fast-paced logistics environments.

value.title: Aurora
value.summary: A conceptual framework to support product work through conversation — centered on intent, shared understanding, and explainable outcomes.
value.role: Product thinking framework developed to support explainable, feedback-driven product decisions

pmBridge.title: How Aurora Shapes My Product Thinking
pmBridge.bullets: Focuses product work on making decisions and system behavior explainable. Encourages framing problems in terms of intent, understanding, and outcome before implementation. Reinforces designing for revision and alignment over time.

impact: Provides a conceptual lens for designing feedback-rich, explainable systems
Informs how I approach product decisions across tools and workflows
